Comment:
This was a fun game that I recently played. I decided to annotate it because I had a pretty good attack and also because I had lost me previous game against this opponent and it was nice to get some revenge.

This is my first annotated game, so if you have any comments on my annotation style I'd appreciate hearing them.
Just a basic Queen's gambit declined
Just a basic Queen's gambit declined
Just a basic Queen's gambit declined
Just a basic Queen's gambit declined
Oddly enough he changes his mind and accepts the gambit. I don't think I've ever seen this before, but maybe it's more common than I think?
So I stick another pawn in the center and attack his pawn at the same time.

I'm not sure why he did this. Not only does he lose his bishop for a knight which is not usually a good trade, but he also allows me to bring a pawn into the middle and it opens the b file for my rook. It does leave my a pawn isolated, but I don't think I would have played this move.

Possibly preparing for b7-b5
Possibly preparing for b7-b5
I develop my other bishop. White has a strong center and a lead in development over black.
I finish developing my minor pieces and prepare to castle. After that, I can look to attack.
I finish developing my minor pieces and prepare to castle. After that, I can look to attack.
Again, he moves his pawn. He really needs to develop his pieces.
I strike at his knight.

One of the benefits of that exchange is it opens a file to his uncastled king.

I pin his knight to his king

Here I should have played Bf4xc7, followed by d5-d6 forking the black queen and knight.

Instead I threaten his rook
Now I notice the move I should have played earlier.
Now I notice the move I should have played earlier.
Perhaps it would have been better for him not to retake?
He evens up the material, but now his queen cannot defend his king from the attack that is to follow.

This allows me to play Re1xe7+ instead of d6xd7

Moving to f8 would let the bishop fall.
